headline: The Software Rout Is Spreading Pain to the Debt Markets
summary: The steep selloff in software stocks is spreading to the debt market.  Pressured by growing worries about the disruptive potential of new AI coding tools, shares of large software companies such as Salesforce and ServiceNow have been sliding for months.

headline: Reassessing ServiceNow (NOW) After A 49.9% One Year Share Price Slide
summary: If you are wondering whether ServiceNow's recent share price slide has created a better entry point, looking closely at what you are paying for each dollar of potential value now matters more than ever. The stock last closed at US$102.63, with returns of 12.1% decline over 7 days, 31.0% decline over 30 days, 30.4% decline year to date and 49.9% decline over 1 year, set against a 10.8% gain over 3 years and 13.7% decline over 5 years. Recent coverage around ServiceNow has focused on how...

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Chomping at the Bitcoin
summary: A broad array of AI-exposed companies saw their shares decline, including software companies, data service firms, hyperscalers, and fund managers that invest in software companies.  Thomson Reuters on its Thursday earnings call argued that their legal-research business cannot be replaced by general-purpose AI models.  The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 fell for the third consecutive trading day.

raw.headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Chomping at the Bitcoin
raw.summary: A broad array of AI-exposed companies saw their shares decline, including software companies, data service firms, hyperscalers, and fund managers that invest in software companies.  Thomson Reuters on its Thursday earnings call argued that their legal-research business cannot be replaced by general-purpose AI models.  The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 fell for the third consecutive trading day.

headline: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
summary: STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment.""For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

raw.headline: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
raw.summary: STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment.""For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

headline: The SaaSpocalypse Has Cut These Stocks In Half
summary: Once upon a time, horse-drawn carriages were the primary means of transportation for those who did not ride horses themselves. The use of horse-drawn carriages lasted for approximately 3,500 years until the invention of the automobile. Since then the horse-drawn carriage has been reduced to a quaint reminder of an earlier time, but an otherwise ... The SaaSpocalypse Has Cut These Stocks In Half

headline: ServiceNow Deepens Anthropic Alliance To Embed Agentic AI In Workflows
summary: ServiceNow (NYSE:NOW) is expanding its work with Anthropic to integrate Claude models directly into core ServiceNow workflows. The companies are rolling out agentic workflow automation for application development and mission critical business processes to customers and employees. The effort includes new AI driven solutions for sectors such as healthcare and financial services. For you as an investor watching NYSE:NOW, this move sits at the intersection of workflow software and applied AI...

headline: AI Rout Erases Nearly $1 Trillion From Software Stocks in Seven Days
summary: Investors sell across software and tech-linked assets as fears grow that AI could disrupt core business models sooner than expected.

headline: US software stocks stabilize after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies steadied on Thursday after a bruising selloff earlier this week that was triggered by fears that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could ​upend the sector.  ServiceNow was up 0.1%, Salesforce slipped 0.2%, while Microsoft dropped 1.8% in premarket trading after sharp ‌falls earlier this week.  The S&P 500 software and services index has shed more than $800 billion in market value over the past six sessions.

The S&P 500 software and services index has shed more than $800 billion in market value over the past six sessions.

headline: Trillion-Dollar Tech Wipeout Ensnares All Stocks in AI’s Path
summary: Nothing, though, quite rivals the rout rippling through stock and credit markets this week.  In the span of two days, hundreds of billions of dollars were wiped off the value of stocks, bonds and loans of companies big and small across Silicon Valley.  “I don’t think it is an overreaction,” said Michael O’Rourke, chief market strategist at Jonestrading.

raw.headline: Trillion-Dollar Tech Wipeout Ensnares All Stocks in AI’s Path

headline: Alphabet plans to double capex spending to a possible $185 billion—but it’s keeping CEO Sundar Pichai up at night
summary: Alphabet revealed a staggering increase in infrastructure investments that will see it nearly double the $91.4 billion it spent last year, according to its fourth quarter earnings release.

headline: How the AI Trade Went From Market Savior to Saboteur
summary: Artificial intelligence may still be in its infancy, but this mainstay of the stock market rally now has investors worried it will be its downfall.
